description:
Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont of Xenochironomus xenolabis is a bacterial endosymbiont that resides within the cells of the midge species Xenochironomus xenolabis. Endosymbionts are organisms that live within the cells of other organisms, often in a mutually beneficial relationship.

This endosymbiont belongs to the phylum Bacteroidetes and is classified as a member of the genus Candidatus Tisiphia. Candidatus Tisiphia is a proposed genus for a group of uncultured bacteria that have been identified through molecular techniques, such as 16S rRNA gene sequencing, in various insect hosts.

The Candidatus Tisiphia endosymbiont of Xenochironomus xenolabis is believed to play a role in the biology and ecology of its host, the midge Xenochironomus xenolabis. Endosymbionts can provide various benefits to their hosts, such as nutritional supplementation, protection against pathogens, or assistance in the breakdown of complex compounds.

However, the specific functions and interactions between this endosymbiont and its host are not yet fully understood, as this bacterial species has not been extensively studied. Further research is needed to elucidate the nature of this symbiotic relationship and the potential implications for the ecology and evolution of both the endosymbiont and the midge host.
